faqs.question: My Sunrise home was built in the 1970s and has a Federal Pacific panel—should I be worried?
faqs.answer: Yes—Federal Pacific panels are a documented fire hazard. Breakers in these panels often fail to trip during overloads, allowing wires to overheat and potentially start fires. If your Sunrise home has a Federal Pacific (FPE) panel, we strongly recommend replacement. These panels were commonly installed in 1970s-80s Sunrise homes, and insurance companies are increasingly requiring their replacement before issuing policies.

faqs.question: Why are my lights flickering in my 1980s Sunrise home?
faqs.answer: Flickering lights in older Sunrise homes typically indicate one of several issues: loose connections at the panel, corroded breakers, overloaded circuits, or problems with the FPL connection. All of these are more common in 40-year-old electrical systems. We can diagnose the specific cause and recommend either targeted repairs or a more comprehensive upgrade depending on what we find.

faqs.question: Can you add outlets in my Sunrise home? We never have enough.
faqs.answer: Definitely—insufficient outlets are a hallmark of 1970s-80s construction. Homes built then typically have far fewer outlets than modern codes require or families need. We can add outlets to any room, including dedicated circuits for high-draw items like space heaters or window AC units. Adding outlets is relatively straightforward and much safer than relying on extension cords and power strips.
